> Please describe what you find dangerous about applying test-first principles
> to an already developed project.


I added "blindly" on purpose.  If you have a large project to maintain, 
don't write tons of tests only to have your project in the same state as 
if it would have been if written from scratch with the tf principles in 
mind.  If you do so, I think you are "blinded" by your "love" for the 
test-first principles.

But I never said that the test-first principles are bad for an already 
developed project.  You only have to keep your head cool and avoid the 
rush.  For me, generating tests is a symptom of this rush ("let's 
quickly have 2,000 tests written for our project").  If 99% of your 
project is already working, why should you first start by writing tests 
for 100% of your code.  Concentrate your effort on the 1% that doesn't work.

One principle of XProgramming is "YAGNI": so don't write tests until you 
need them.  And keep in mind that the goal is not to write tons of 
tests, but to validate your code.

-Vladimir
